AU: Kim, SK; Miyayama, M; Yanagida, H
AF: Kim, SK; Miyayama, M; Yanagida, H
TI: Electrical anisotropy and a plausible explanation for dielectric anomaly of Bi4Ti3O12 single crystal
ID: POLYCRYSTALLINE SOLID ELECTROLYTES; BISMUTH TITANATE; AC IMPEDANCE
AB: The electrical anisotropy of layer-structured bismuth titanate (Bi4Ti3O12) has been investigated by measurements of Seebeck coefficient, dielectric permittivity, DC conductivity, and complex impedance on single- and polycrystalline samples, and a plausible explanation for the origin of dielectric anomaly below Curie temperature has been suggested. A large anisotropy in the dielectric permittivity, DC conductivity and activation energy for charge transport was observed between the parallel/perpendicular direction to the bismuth oxide layer ((Bi2O2)(2+) layer. Complex impedance and modulus spectroscopy on single crystals in the direction perpendicular to the bismuth oxide layer below the Curie temperature confirmed that there are large differences in the electrical resistivity and, in particular, capacitance between the parallel/perpendicular direction to the bismuth oxide layer, which is assumed to be due to the difference in the electrical nature of the bismuth oxide layer and the pseudo-perovskite block. The dielectric anomaly below the Curie temperature is thought to originate from the space charge due to the thermally agitated polarization fluctuation.

AU: Hu, ZJ; Iwasaki, H; Takeichi, M
AF: Hu, ZJ; Iwasaki, H; Takeichi, M
TI: Construction of list homomorphisms by tupling and fusion
CT: 21st International Symposium on Mathematical Foundations of Computer Science (MFCS 96)
CL: JAGIELLONIAN UNIV, POLONIA INST, KRAKOW, POLAND
SP: Polish Acad Sci, Inst Comp Sci, Warsaw Univ, Inst Informat, European Assoc Theoret Comp Sci, ICS PAS, Warsaw Univ, ICIS Project, Microsoft Poland, SUN Poland, Batory Fdn, State Comm Sci Res, Warsaw
AB: List homomorphisms are functions which can be efficiently computed in parallel since they ideally suit the divide-and-conquer paradigm. However, some interesting functions, e.g., the maximum segment sum problem, are not list homomorphisms. In this paper, we propose a systematic way of embedding them into list homomorphisms so that parallel programs are derived. We show, with an example, how a simple, and ''obviously'' correct, but possibly inefficient solution to the problem can be successfully turned into a semantically equivalent almost homomorphism by means of two transformations: tupling and fusion.

AU: Kawazumi, N; Morita, S
AF: Kawazumi, Nariya; Morita, Shigeyuki
TI: THE PRIMARY APPROXIMATION TO THE COHOMOLOGY OF THE MODULI SPACE OF CURVES AND COCYCLES FOR THE STABLE CHARACTERISTIC CLASSES
AB: The purpose of the present note is to announce our recent results on the cohomology of the moduli space of curves or equivalently (over the rationals) the cohomology of the mapping class group of orientable surfaces. Our main results are twofold. First we construct explicit group cocycles for any of the known stable characteristic classes (the Mumford-MoritaMiller classes) of the moduli spaces. Secondly, by combining our result with that of Hain in [H2], we show that the "continuous part" of the collomology of the moduli space (see 5 for the definition) is exactly equal to the subalgebra generated by the above stable classes. This second result may be considered as a supporting evidence for the conjecture that the stable cohomology of the moduli spaces would be equal to the polynomial algebra generated by the Mumford-Morita-Miller classes. The details of the results sketched in this note will appear elsewhere.

AU: Warren, PH; Kallemeyn, GW
AF: Warren, PH; Kallemeyn, GW
TI: Siderophile trace elements in ALH84001, other SNC meteorites and eucrites: Evidence of heterogeneity, possibly time-linked, in the mantle of Mars
ID: RE-OS; PARENT BODY; PETROGENESIS; BASALTS; ORIGIN; SYSTEMATICS; SHERGOTTY; LEW88516; ISOTOPE; EARTH
AB: We report neutron activation analyses, including radiochemical determination of trace siderophile elements (Au, Ge, Ir, Ni, Os and Re), for three SNC/martian meteorites, and Os and Re results for numerous eucrites. Ratios such as Ga/Al in the SNC orthopyroxenite ALH84001 confirm its martian affinity-its many distinctive characteristics, most notably its near-primordial age, notwithstanding. To the list of ALH84001's idiosyncrasies can now be added extraordinarily low concentrations of Au, Ni and, especially, Re (17 pg/g), for a martian meteorite. We consider several possible origins for the anomalously low Re content in ALH84001, including metasomatism or alteration. The pyroxene-cumulate nature of this rock probably does not account for its low Re content. Other SNC meteorites are also cumulates. An examination of Re-Nd variations among terrestrial basalts and komatiites suggests that Re is compatible with mantle minerals in general and only incompatible with olivine (however, olivine dominates the mantle residuum, especially during komatiite genesis). Our preferred model is that the ALH84001 parent melt formed in a mantle source region that was far more Re-depleted, and/or at a substantially lower oxygen fugacity, than the sources of the young SNC meteorites. Such a contrast is consistent with models that replenish siderophile elements in planetary mantles by gradual admixture of late-accreting matter and similarly derive most planetary water (which serves as an oxidant) very late in accretion. According to this model, ALH84001 formed before the siderophile-rich matter and water had been mixed well into the martian interior. Possibly the martian mantle never became generally as Re-rich and/or oxidized as the source region(s) of the younger SNCs.

TI: Different rifampicin inactivation mechanisms in Nocardia and related taxa
DE: mycolic acid-containing bacteria; rifampicin; inactivation; species-specific
ID: RHODOCOCCUS
AB: Mycolic acid-containing bacteria inactivate rifampicin in a variety of ways such as glucosylation, ribosylation, phosphorylation and decolorization. These inactivations were found to be a species-specific phenomena in Nocardia and related taxa. Gordona, Tsukamurella and fast-growing Mycobacterium modified rifampicin by ribosylation of the 23-OH group of the antibiotic. Such ribosylation was not observed in Rhodococcus and Corynebacterium, but phosphorylation of the 21-OH group of rifampicin was observed in one strain of Rhodococcus. Nocardia modified the antibiotic by glucosylation (23-OH group) and phosphorylation, but ribosylation was not observed.

TI: Detection and sequencing of Norwalk-like viruses from stool samples in Japan using reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction amplification
DE: Norwalk-like virus; RT-PCR; gene; epidemiology
ID: IMMUNE ELECTRON-MICROSCOPY; ROUND-STRUCTURED VIRUSES; GASTROENTERITIS; ORGANIZATION; SPECIMENS; AGENT
AB: Norwalk-like viruses were detected in Japan in 12% (26/209) of patients with nonbacteria and nonrotavirus gastroenteritis in an outpatient clinic of a hospital from 1991 to 1994 by reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction. They were also present in 7% (26/378) of total samples including those from rotavirus-positive gastroenteritis patients. In addition, the viruses were recovered in samples from 15 of 17 patients which were collected during outbreaks of gastroenteritis in various places in Japan by the same method. The DNA sequence of the polymerase region from patients at the hospital (sporadic cases) showed that two subgenogroups, similar to UK1-6 in genogroup G1 and to UK1-1 in genogroup G2 (Ando et al, J Clin Microbiol, 1995, 33: 64-71) exist in Japan. The latter was more frequently found.

AU: Mae, K; Kyuno, K; Yamamoto, R
AF: Mae, K; Kyuno, K; Yamamoto, R
TI: The microscopic mechanism of surfactant epitaxy by molecular dynamics
SO: MODELLING AND SIMULATION IN MATERIALS SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING
ID: EMBEDDED-ATOM POTENTIALS; GROWTH; SILICON; SUBMONOLAYER; GERMANIUM; SB
AB: Surfactant epitaxy has been expected to be a powerful method to improve thin-film growth from 3D island to layered growth, but the atomic level process of surfactant epitaxy has not been revealed yet. The purpose of this paper is to elucidate the phenomenon of surfactant epitaxy by molecular dynamic simulations. It is found that a smaller surface energy is necessary for the surfactant to be stable on the surface and that the difference of the atomic radii between the surfactant and the adatom plays an important role in the process of quick exchange of their positions.

AU: Nakamura, N; Nakajima, S; Arima, T; Ichikawa, J
AF: Nakamura, N; Nakajima, S; Arima, T; Ichikawa, J
TI: Full-scale test of a wooden structure with an octagonal shape
DE: full-scale test; octagonal shape; lateral loading; vertical loading; strength
AB: Lateral and vertical loadings were conducted on a full-scale wooden structure with an octagonal shape. The strength of the structure and the effects of the bearing walls arranged 45 degrees to the lateral load were evaluated. The results are summarized as follows: (1) The roof of the structure with an octagonal shape could be considered as a diaphragm. (2) The effects of the strength and the initial stiffness of the bearing walls arranged 45 degrees to the lateral load were different in the bracing and sheathing arrangements. (3) Generally the strength of structures, including the type without the bearing walls parallel to the lateral load, were about 10% under the strength calculated from the Standard for Structural Calculation of Timber Structures. (4) In the stage of bracing only, the strength and the initial stiffness were the almost same as the structure with a rectangular shape that had the same amount of bearing walls. (5) The structure had enough strength for a vertical load corresponding to about a 50 cm thick deep snowfall.

AU: Dong, ZH; Okuma, M
AF: Dong, ZH; Okuma, M
TI: Development of a new structural sheet material, LSB (long stick board) .3. Manufacturing and fundamental properties of LSB made from chopstick elements
DE: chopstick; recycling; composite panel; orientations of elements; bending properties
AB: The chopstick demand increases from time to time in Japan. According to Japanese statistics, about 4,830,000 pairs were used in 1990. This volume is equivalent to 500,000 m(3) raw material, a considerable volume. In this research, recycled chopsticks were used as an element for board production. This kind of board can be composed similarly to the construction of composite panels. Face and back layers can use veneers, chips, or fibers, and would be called a 3-ply composite panel. Furthermore, the chopstick core orientation could be either random or oriented. All of the chopstick boards have bending properties which exceed those of JIS A 5908 (Japan Industrial Standard) for 8-type particleboard. Oriented core boards have bending properties greater than random boards because of the orientations of the chopsticks. These oriented boards are composed of an element arrangement like plywood to increase the isotropic properties. However, if the cross-section surface area of the element is large such as for chopsticks, the thickness swelling will be very large. This explains why all the thickness swelling values were larger than allowed (limited to 12%) by JIS A 5908. The thickness swelling property is one area in which improvements are desired.
RP: Dong, ZH (reprint author), UNIV TOKYO, FAC AGR, BUNKYO KU, TOKYO 113, JAPAN.
PA: 1-1-17, MUKOGAOKA, BUNKYO-KU, TOKYO, 113-0023, JAPAN

AU: Dong, ZH; Okuma, M
AF: Dong, ZH; Okuma, M
TI: Development of a new structural sheet material, LSB (long stick board) .4. Properties of the board made from chopsticks pretreated by hot pressing
DE: chopsticks; recycling; wood-based board; hot-press treatment; thickness swelling
AB: This research was conducted to improve the thickness swelling properties of chopstick boards. The chopstick elements used in this research mere pressed under various conditions of hot pressing, and the efficiency of this method was investigated. The results of this research were as follows: 1. If the chopstick moisture content was more than 18%, the pressing temperature of 180 degrees C for three minutes was enough to change the chopstick form into a stable size. Further investigation showed that the spring-back ratio of the thickness of hot-pressed chopsticks after immersion in boiling water for one minute was not more than 3%. 2. Sample boards were made of hot-pressed chopstick elements. The chopstick boards (only core element prepressed by hot press) had bending properties not less than those of control boards. This phenomena probably was due to the fact that heat and pressure treatment of the press had no detrimental effects on the chopsticks. Rather, it led to the improvement of the adhesive joints among the elements. 3. The thickness swelling of the pressed chopstick boards decreased about 1/3 of the amount of the control board on the average. This probably was because the heat- and pressure-treated chopsticks were more dimensionally stable. Therefore, thickness swellings of all of the boards were less than 12% meeting the requirements set forth in JAS A 5908 (Japan Industrial Standard). 4. The chopstick pressed boards had relatively large bending retentions after two hours of boiling, about 70% for MOR and about 60% for MOE.

AU: Lam, TBT; Iiyama, K
AF: Lam, TBT; Iiyama, K
TI: Role of ferulic acid bridges between lignin and polysaccharides in the growth of wheat (Triticum aestivum) internodes
DE: Triticum aestivum; isogenic dwarf line; ferulic acid bridges; lignin-polysaccharide associations; mechanical properties
ID: ALKALINE NITROBENZENE OXIDATION; CELL-WALL EXTENSIBILITY; DEEP-WATER RICE; PHENOLIC-ACIDS; MECHANICAL-PROPERTIES; COLEOPTILES; MATURATION; FRACTIONS; POLYMERS; PHALARIS
AB: The internodes and leaf sheath walls of isogenic and near-isogenic lines of wheat (Triticum aestivum L. em Thell) with varying dosages of dwarfing genes have been analyzed for lignin contents and monosaccharide and hydroxycinnamic acid compositions. Both lignin and glucose contents of the first four internodes from the top showed a clear positive correlation with the length of the first internode (topmost, used as an index of dwarfism), but the ratio of syringyl nuclei to guaiacyl nuclei (S/V ratio) of lignin, determined by alkaline nitrobenzene oxidation, and xylose contents were independent of the first internode length. When compared with lines carrying dwarfing genes, wall components of normal (taller) wheat plants were characterised by a greater content of etherified ferulic acids which also are esterified to form bridges between lignin and polysaccharides, and a smaller content of ferulic acid linked only by esterification. It is suggested that matrix components of the wall are reinforced with bridging by ferulic acid etherified to lignin and to polysaccharides and that they are quantitatively more numerous in normal (taller) lines.

AU: Fujita, M; Takemura, A; Mizumachi, H
AF: Fujita, M; Takemura, A; Mizumachi, H
TI: Compatibility of polymethyl methacrylate/cellulose blends
DE: cellulose; saccharide-pendanted polymers; blends; compatibility; glass transition temperatures
ID: N,N-DIMETHYLACETAMIDE LITHIUM-CHLORIDE; CELLULOSE
AB: To promote compatibility between the daily-used polymer polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) and cellulose, methyl methacrylate was copolymerized with an isocyanate compound, and glucose or celloheptaose was suspended from the resulting copolymers. Copolymers and the saccharide-pendanted polymers were blended with cellulose in nine different weight ratios in N,N-dimethylacetamide/LiCl (DMAc/LiCl) solutions, and then the blended solutions were coagulated with isopropyl alcohol followed by drying. Compatibilities of the solid blends were investigated by measuring glass transition temperatures (Tg) using differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). All of the polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) derivatives synthesized in this study were partially compatible with cellulose, and the celloheptaose-pendanted polymer was a little more compatible with cellulose. Infrared (IR) absorption spectra of the blends indicated that the compatibility between a copolymer and cellulose was caused by the urethane bonds of the two components and that the compatibility between a saccharide-pendanted polymer and cellulose was caused by hydrogen bonds.

AU: Yoshihara, H; Sasaki, K; Ohta, M
AF: Yoshihara, H; Sasaki, K; Ohta, M
TI: Deformation of wood in a biaxial-stress state .1. Examination of the biaxial-compression testing method
DE: biaxial-compression test; partial compression; elastic modulus; yield surface; failure surface
AB: In this study, we examined the stress-strain relationship of wood during biaxial-compression loading. The material used for the experiment was Sitka spruce (Picea sitchensis Carr.). To apply the compression forces biaxially, one direction is obliged to be loaded partially even when the other direction is full-surface loaded. Hence, previous to the biaxial compression tests, partial uniaxial-compression tests and finite element calculations simulating this loading condition were made for determining the specimen's shape. Then the biaxial-compression tests were made under various testing conditions. The results obtained were summarized as follows: (1) In biaxial-compression, the direction with the weaker stiffness should be loaded partially, and the full-surface compression load should be applied along the direction with the stronger stiffness. (2) The frictional forces which disturb the ideal biaxial-stress condition could be reduced effectively by inserting a Teflon plate between the compressing plate and the test specimen. (3) Although the frictional forces were reduced as much as possible, the yield and failure surfaces were distorted in the tangential direction in the stress space. This phenomenon could not be expressed by the Hill-type yield (failure) criteria which are often used.

AU: Shida, S
AF: Shida, S
TI: Application of the logistic function for drying curves of softwood columns
DE: logistic function; softwood drying; Japanese cedar; column; drying curve
ID: BOUND WATER; DIFFUSION; WOOD
AB: Green columns of Japanese cedar (Cryptomeria japonica D. Don) were kiln-dried under constant drying conditions. The drying curves contained a linear part like a constant rate of the drying stage. Therefore, the illustration of the relationship between drying rate, v, and drying time, t, was a sigmoid curve. A logistic function, Eq. (3), was conducted to approximate the v-t relationship because a logistic function also has a sigmoid curve. Equation (3) is founded on the assumption that the change of drying rate, dv/dt, is proportional to v and it showed resistance which is proportional to v(2) and was well-fitted to the v-t relational data. Eq.(4), which expresses the drying curve, was obtained by integrating Eq. (3) with respect to t, and it expressed the drying curves of the columns very well. Eq. (4) consists of several terms. The first term is for the initial moisture content. The second term is for a constant rate of drying. The third term is the resistance term for the falling rate of dry inp. This function has the possibility of approximation the drying curves which are obtained by the drying of columns having both drying stages at the constant rate of drying and the falling rate of drying.

AU: Sakuma, H; Okuma, M
AF: Sakuma, H; Okuma, M
TI: Development of new systems for glulam timber construction with tightening bolts .1. Bending properties of glulam timber beams, prestressed longitudinally by tightening bolts
DE: hollow core; pre-stressed glulam beam; end-resistant moment; apparent MOE; bending strength
AB: Bending properties of glulam timber beams pre-stressed longitudinally by steel bolts (PSG-beams) were investigated. A PSG-beam is composed of glulam timber, which has some hollow cores inside arranged longitudinally with some steel bolts put through the hollow cores and tightened at both ends of the beam with nuts and washers. The results of the three-point bending tests oi the PSG-beams showed significantly larger values in both stiffness and strength in bending than those of normal glulam timber beams without steel bolts. Assuming- the generation model of the end-resistant moment produced by the changes of tension in bolts located at some distance from the neutral line of the beam, the rate of increase in bending stiffness or apparent modulus of elasticity in bending (E(a)) of the PSG-beam can be calculated theoretically, E(a) calculated values by means of the model were very similar to the E(a) experimental values. Furthermore, by the effects of the end-resistant moment and compressive axial forces, the apparent bending strength of the PSG-beams were observed to increase. From the experimental results, the rates of increase in apparent bending strength of PSG-beams were 10 to 40% in comparison with glulam beams without bolts.

AU: Yoshihara, H; Ohta, M
AF: Yoshihara, H; Ohta, M
TI: Analysis of the yield behavior of wood under combined shear stresses in torsion tests
DE: yield criterion; shear stress; torsion test; ring angle; grain angle
AB: The yield behavior of wood under combined-shear stress conditions was examined by the torsion of rectangular bars. Sitka spruce (Picea sitchensis Carr.) and konara (Japanese oak, Quercus serrate Murray) were used for the specimens. Torsion tests were made in the following two series. In the first series, specimens were cut so as to have angles between the annual rings and the geometrical axis, which were defined as the ''ring angles''. Each specimen was twisted around the longitudinal axis, and various combined-shear stress conditions were given for the LT- (longitudinal-tangential) and LR- (longitudinal-radial) planes by varying the ring angles. In the other series, specimens were cut so as to have angles between the grain and the geometrical axes, which were defined as the ''grain angles''. Each specimen was twisted around the radial axis, and various combined-shear stress conditions were given for the RT (radial-tangential) and LR-planes by varying the grain angles. Yield shear stresses corresponding to the ring angles and grain angles were obtained, and the applicabilities of Hill-type and Jenkin's yield criteria, which are the most famous ones, were examined. Consequently, we concluded that the Hill-type criterion was most applicable in describing the yield of wood under combined shear-stress conditions.

AU: Aratake, S; Arima, T
AF: Aratake, S; Arima, T
TI: Creep of sugi full sized members .2. Behaviors under various loading conditions of loads and estimations by deformation models
DE: creep; sawn lumber; glulam; power law; superposition
AB: Bending creep deflections and recoveries under various loading conditions of sugi (Cryptomeria japonica D. Don) full sized members were investigated under ambient conditions. In addition, based on the power law model, the obtained creep deflections and recoveries were evaluated quantitatively by the superposition theory and the cumulative deflections due to intermittent loading periods summed together. The experiment was conducted with sawn lumber (green and kilin-dried at the start of the creep tests) and glulam. The specimen dimensions were 10.5 cm in width, 21.0 cm in depth, and 400 cm in length. Stress was applied under four point loading conditions, and the stress levels were changed according to the order of 11% (one year), 22% (one year), 33% (one year), 22% (two months), 33% (two months), 11% (three months), 33% (three months), and 0% (three months). The results are summarized as follows: 1) The experimental values of creep deflections of glulam were very small in comparison with those of sawn lumber (green and kiln-dried), regardless of the stress levels. 2) The experimental values of total deflections were approximately in the range of deformation models [superposition type (S.P.), additional duration type (A.D.), and maximum duration type (M.D.)]. Then, those of sawn lumber (green and kiln-dried) were separated gradually from the deformation model in the direction of the safety side, after increasing the stress levels of S.P. and A.D., and after decreasing (or removal of load) the stress levels of A.D. and M.D.. In addition, those of glulam were separated gradually from the deformation model in the direction of the safety side, after decreasing (or removal of load) the stress levels of A.D. and M.D.. 3) For the experimental values of total deflections after decreasing (or removal of load) the stress levels, S.P. can be evaluated most accurately among the deformation models.

AU: Kim, Y; Kurahashi, A; Meshitsuka, G
AF: Kim, Y; Kurahashi, A; Meshitsuka, G
TI: Characteristics of the chemical structure of lignin in fast-growing poplar (Populus maximowiczii Henry)
DE: fast-growing poplar; vessel; fiber; lignin; nitrobenzene oxidation
ID: ACETYL BROMIDE PROCEDURE; HETEROGENEITY; GUAIACYL; XYLEM
AB: Woods having excellent qualities and forms for utilization have recently been developed by the hybridization between different species and/or between different strains in same species of woody plants. However, little knowledge is available about the chemical characteristics of these woods. In this paper, the morphological aspects and structural features of lignins in the cell walls of fast-growing poplar (Populus maximowiczii Henry) are discussed by comparing them with normal strains based on microscopical observations and chemical analyses. A greater diameter increase of the fast-growing poplar wood than that of normal poplar wood was characterized by the number of cells in the radial direction of an annual ring, but not by the size of the cells and the ratio of the number of vessels to that of fibers. Lignin in the fast-growing poplar wood fibers contained slightly higher amounts of syringyl units and condensed guaiacyl units than lignin in normal poplar wood. Because lignin in the differentiating xylem of the fast-growing poplar wood had no particular difference in its chemical structure from that of normal poplar wood, the above differences are attributed to the nature of the secondary-wall lignin.

AU: Shida, S; Koike, M
AF: Shida, S; Koike, M
TI: Utilization and evaluation of exterior wood .6. Radiant performances of materials influencing sensory warmth perceptions
DE: infrared-radiation thermometer; emissivity; radiant heat; exterior wood; heat-flow meter
ID: DECK
AB: Emissivity and radiant heats of materials are the fundamental values in determining the sensory warmth caused by reradiated heat emitted from construction materials, such as exterior wood which absorbs solar radiant heat. In this report, emissivities of several materials were measured by a simplified measuring method using an infrared radiation thermometer, and the heat emitted from the materials was measured by a heat-flow sensor. The results were as follows: 1) Emissivity of wood and wood-based materials could be measured by an infrared radiation thermometer. It was difficult to correctly measure for materials having low emissivities like copper and aluminum or those having great transparencies like glass and polyvinyl chloride plates. 2) Rusted iron showed an emissivity similar to wood. 3) For radiant heat from materials heated at 45 degrees C, stainless steel had the minimum radiant heat of 26 W/m(2). Other materials showed similar values in the range of 50-70 W/m(2). Japanese cedar (sugi, Cryptmeria japonica D. Don) and Japanese cypress (hinoki, Chamaecyparis obtusa (S. and Z.) Endl.) showed relatively small radiant heat. Japanese red pine (akamatsu, Pinus densiflora S. and Z.) had the maximum value of 70 W/m(2).

AF: Hirata, S; Okano, T; Ohta, M
TI: Deviations of kerf by handsaws .2. Sequential cutting by two model teeth of symmetrical shapes
CT: 40th Anniversary Conference of the Japan-Wood-Research-Society
DE: deviation of kerf; crosscut handsaw; single model tooth; lateral force; chip formation
AB: To clarify the mechanism of the kerf deviation of crosscut teeth of a handsaw, lateral forces of cutting resistances were measured using two single model teeth, which had symmetrical shapes and were set to the left and right sides simulating saw teeth. Agathis spp, wood was used as a workpiece material. The following sequeintial cuttings were made: first, a flat workpiece was cut by a model tooth, and then a second cutting was made by another model tooth with a certain kerf width, The following results were obtained: 1. In the first cutting, there was no chip formation, and a lateral force was generated in the direction from the rake face to the major flank. All partial forces were increased with the increase of the cutting depth. 2. In the second cutting, chips were not generated for large kerf widths, and the results obtained were almost the same as that of the first cutting. 3. When the kerf width was small, chips were generated and the measured lateral force was very small. 4. In the second cutting, the effect of the side clearance angle of set on the cutting forces was much smaller than that of the depth of cut. 5. From the analysis of the composed lateral forces on the pair-tooth, it was found that the imbalance of the cutting depth rules the induced lateral forces for large kerf widths, whereas the first cutting condition is very important for the small kerf widths. This fact would have a concern with the mechanism of the kerf deviation in the initiating process of handsawing.

AU: Nishimura, T; Okuma, M
AF: Nishimura, T; Okuma, M
TI: Development of low-density wood based boards considering the distribution of elements .1. Distribution of elements for the purpose of efficient load communication
DE: low density board; wood based board; distribution of elements; efficient load communication
AB: Load communication efficiency by distributing fewer elements was investigated. To be more concrete, models with varied distributions of elements and their voids filled with styrene were constructed and tested in bending. Styrene was used so as to exert very little influence upon the models' specific gravities. Then, various kinds of elements were designed and assembled to realize the distribution of elements. Specimens were constructed with each kind of element and tested in compression and bending. The results suggested the following about the design of low-density wood based boards: 1) Truss type models communicate loads most efficiently with fewer elements in bending. 2) The stability of the distribution of elements was improved by filling the voids. 3) Designing the shapes of elements and distributing them three-dimensionally makes efficient load communication possible. Thus, connecting the elements strongly allows the board to retain a low density while attaining great strength.

AU: Yamada, T; Ono, H; Ohara, S; Yamaguchi, A
AF: Yamada, T; Ono, H; Ohara, S; Yamaguchi, A
TI: Characterization of the products resulting from direct liquefaction of cellulose .1. Identification of intermediates and the relevant mechanism in direct phenol liquefaction of cellulose in the presence of water
CT: 43rd Annual Meeting of the Japan-Wood-Research-Society
DE: phenol liquefaction; cellulose; 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF); GPC; NMR
ID: WOOD LIQUEFACTION; TEMPERATURE; CATALYST
AB: The liquefaction of cellulose process in the presence of water was investigated to characterize period suggests that the liquefaction provides degradation products following a pseudo-first order reaction. The fractionation of the products gives low molecular weight intermediates identified as 5-hydroxymethulfurfural (HMF), oligo-saccharides, and glucose. This finding reveal that the reaction mechanism involves the formation sequence of glucose from cellulose via oligo-saccharides and HMF from glucose. The formation of HMF may lead to the reaction with phenol and/or of HMF by itself, resulting in compounds furan ring structures. The further reaction may yield a crosslinking polymer which would be responsible in part for the increase of acetone insoluble residue in the late stage of the liquefaction.

AU: Kubojima, Y; Yoshihara, H; Ohta, M; Okano, T
AF: Kubojima, Y; Yoshihara, H; Ohta, M; Okano, T
TI: Examination of the method of measuring the shear modulus of wood based on the Timoshenko theory of bending
DE: shear modulus; Timoshenko theory; bending; vibration mode; length/depth ratio
ID: FLEXURAL VIBRATION
AB: The objective of this study was to evaluate the method of measuring the shear modulus of wood based on the Timoshenko theory of bending. Flexural vibration tests were made with rectangular beams of Sitka spruce (Picea sitchensis Carr.). The shear moduli were calculated using two procedures: one the Mead-Joannides method, and the other the Goens-Hearmon regression. The Young's moduli which are necessary to obtain the shear moduli by the Mead-Joannides method were measured using longitudinal vibration tests and the Goens-Hearmon regression method. The shear moduli from the flexural vibration tests were compared with those by the torsion tests. The shear moduli by the Mead-Joannides method were influenced by the Young's moduli given for the calculations and were not adequate when the contribution of the shear deflection was small. On the contrary, the shear moduli obtained using the greater resonance modes had enough accuracy. The shear moduli by the Goens-Hearmon regression method were not reliable when the contribution was small. Thus, Re concluded that the shear moduli obtained by the Goens-Hearmon regression method should be obtained using adequate resonance modes after trial-and-error calculations using various resonance modes.

AU: Massijaya, MY; Okuma, M
AF: Massijaya, MY; Okuma, M
TI: Development of boards made from waste newspapers .1. Production and fundamental properties of waste-newspaper boards
CT: 40th Anniversary Conference of the Japan-Wood-Research-Society
DE: waste-newspaper board; internal bond; modulus of rupture; modulus of elasticity; thickness swelling
ID: FEASIBILITY
AB: This research concerns the development of boards made from waste newspapers. The boards were produced from particle waste newspapers to reduce energy consumption in the board production process. Waste-newspaper boards bonded with urea formaldehyde and phenol formaldehyde adhesives were produced on a laboratory scare, and their physical and mechanical properties were examined. The average density of the waste newspapers was 0.58 g/cm(3), and the densities of the boards were 0.50-0.90 g/cm(3). Therefore, the compaction ratios of the boards were in the range of 0.86-1.55. The results obtained were as follows: 1) An increase in board density results in a corresponding improvement in bending properties. Modulus of rupture (MOR) properties for the boards of a density of 0.80 g/cm(3) exceeded the minimum value established for 8-type particleboard by Japanese Industrial Standard (JIS) A 5908;(2)) 2) An increase in board density results in increased internal bond strength: However, internal bond values of all of the samples were relatively small compared to the minimum value established for g-type particleboard by JIS A 5908 (not less than 1.5 kgf/cm(2)); 3) In this research, modulus of elasticity (MOE) and thickness swelling properties of urea formaldehyde bonded boards had better properties than phenol formaldehyde bonded boards; 4) Waste-newspaper board can be used only for interior applications. To gain exterior applications, the dimensional stability properties (thickness swelling and water absorption) need to be improved.

AU: Li, XL; Ohannesian, DW; Yoshida, M; Beppu, T; Lotan, R
AF: Li, XL; Ohannesian, DW; Yoshida, M; Beppu, T; Lotan, R
TI: Induction of galectin-1 expression in human colon carcinoma cells by histone deacetylase inhibitors
DE: trichostatin A; histone deacetylase; galectin-1
ID: GALACTOSIDE-BINDING-PROTEIN; TRANSFORMED NIH3T3 CELLS; TRICHOSTATIN-A; SODIUM-BUTYRATE; LECTIN GENE; DIFFERENTIATION; TRANSCRIPTION; ADHESION; TRAPOXIN; GROWTH
AB: (R)-trichostatin A {(R)-TSA; 7-[4-(dimethylamino)phenyl]-N-hydroxy-4,6-dimethyl-7-oxo-2,4-heptadien-amide}, a potent histone deacetylase inhibitor, was found to suppress cell proliferation, suppress the transformed phenotype, and enhance the differentiation of various malignant cells, including the KM12 human colon carcinoma cells. We found that KM12 cells treated with (R)-TSA for 3 h exhibited a high degree of histone H4 acetylation. (R)-TSA induced the expression of galectin-1, a 14.5-kDa galactoside-binding protein, at concentrations in the range between 0.1 to 1 mu M that are at least 1000 times lower than those required to achieve similar effects by n-butyrate, another histone deacetylase inhibitor, which we have shown previously to induce galectin-1 in the KM12 cells. The effect of (R)-TSA was observed at both the mRNA and protein levels as early as 6 h after treatment. Trichostatin C, which exhibits some histone deacetylase inhibitory activity, but not the analogs (S)-TSA or (R)- or (S)-trichostatic acid, which lack histone deacetylase inhibitory activity, also showed some induction of galectin-1. (R)-TSA enhanced the transactivation of galectin-1 promoter-reporter constructs. These results indicate that the effect of (R)-TSA on galectin-1 expression was, at least in part, at the level of transcription.
